title: Nishikori conquers cramp, Munar in Indian Wells opener
description: Kei Nishikori returned to BNP Paribas Open action in dramatic fashion on Wednesday in Indian Wells. Competing at the hard-court ATP Masters 1000 for the first time since 2021, Nishikori overcame physical struggles to down a fired-up Jaume Munar 6-2, 5-7, 7-6(3) and earn a second-round spot. The former World No. 4 called for the physio for a leg injury midway through the third set and within two games was also struggling with cramp, but he nonetheless held firm for a two-hour, 57-minute victory. ‚ÄúIt was not easy. I almost gave up because I was struggling with my body,‚Äù said Nishikori. ‚ÄúIn the third set I was cramping pretty badly, but somehow I came back and won, so a very good match.‚Äù Earned not given ü•ã In just under three hours, @keinishikori sets up a second round meeting with No. 18 seed Humbert! @BNPPARIBASOPEN | #TennisParadise pic.twitter.com/VzQWySsuqr ‚Äî ATP Tour (@atptour) March 5, 2025 Nishikori has battled back from long-term injury to reestablish himself in the Top 100 of the PIF ATP Rankings, and in January he reached his first ATP Tour final for six years in Hong Kong. Currently the World No. 76, he seemed set for a routine victory in his maiden Lexus ATP Head2Head meeting with Munar after making a fast start, but the match became complicated after he let slip a 4-3 lead with a break in the second set. ‚ÄúI knew I was playing well from the beginning, and he took the chance in the second set, but even then, I was still happy with my tennis,‚Äù reflected Nishikori. ‚ÄúI just tried to stay focused and I think he had more chances in the third set, but I tried to compete and fight until the end.‚Äù After saving 10 of 14 break points he faced against Munaur in Indian Wells, according to Infosys ATP Stats, Nishikori set a second-round meeting with 18th seed Ugo Humbert. [HOT SHOT] In other early Day 1 action in the California desert, wild card Tristan Boyer enjoyed a dream Masters 1000 main-draw debut by securing a 4-6, 6-2, 7-6(4) victory against Aleksandar Vukic. Boyer, whose only previous match in Indian Wells was a first-round qualifying encounter as a 16-year-old seven years ago, will next take on his countryman and 10th seed Tommy Paul. Thiago Seyboth Wild and Christopher O‚ÄôConnell each notched three-set triumphs to kick-start their BNP Paribas Open campaigns. Seyboth Wild saved two match points in the deciding set before prevailing 4-6, 7-5, 7-6(6) against Alexandre Muller, while O‚ÄôConnell won a topsy-turvy duel with Roberto Carballes Baena 6-3, 0-6, 6-1. In the second round, Seyboth Wild will take on last week‚Äôs Dubai champion Stefanos Tsitsipas, while O‚ÄôConnell plays Matteo Berrettini. [NEWSLETTER FORM]
excerpt: Kei Nishikori returned to BNP Paribas action in dramatic fashion on Wednesday in Indian Wells. The Japanese overcame physical struggles and a fired-up Jaume Munar 6-2, 5-7, 7-6(3) to reach the second round.

html:
Match Report

Nishikori conquers cramp, Munar in Indian Wells opener

Wild card Boyer advances, Seyboth Wild saves 2 MPs

March 05, 2025

Andrew Eichenholz/ATP Tour

Kei Nishikori defeats Jaume Munar on Wednesday at the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells. By ATP Staff

Kei Nishikori returned to BNP Paribas Open action in dramatic fashion on Wednesday in Indian Wells.

Competing at the hard-court ATP Masters 1000 for the first time since 2021, Nishikori overcame physical struggles to down a fired-up Jaume Munar 6-2, 5-7, 7-6(3) and earn a second-round spot. The former World No. 4 called for the physio for a leg injury midway through the third set and within two games was also struggling with cramp, but he nonetheless held firm for a two-hour, 57-minute victory.

‚ÄúIt was not easy. I almost gave up because I was struggling with my body,‚Äù said Nishikori. ‚ÄúIn the third set I was cramping pretty badly, but somehow I came back and won, so a very good match.‚Äù

‚Äî ATP Tour (@atptour) March 5, 2025

Nishikori has battled back from long-term injury to reestablish himself in the Top 100 of the PIF ATP Rankings, and in January he reached his first ATP Tour final for six years in Hong Kong. Currently the World No. 76, he seemed set for a routine victory in his maiden Lexus ATP Head2Head meeting with Munar after making a fast start, but the match became complicated after he let slip a 4-3 lead with a break in the second set.

‚ÄúI knew I was playing well from the beginning, and he took the chance in the second set, but even then, I was still happy with my tennis,‚Äù reflected Nishikori. ‚ÄúI just tried to stay focused and I think he had more chances in the third set, but I tried to compete and fight until the end.‚Äù

After saving 10 of 14 break points he faced against Munaur in Indian Wells, according to Infosys ATP Stats, Nishikori set a second-round meeting with 18th seed Ugo Humbert.

In other early Day 1 action in the California desert, wild card Tristan Boyer enjoyed a dream Masters 1000 main-draw debut by securing a 4-6, 6-2, 7-6(4) victory against Aleksandar Vukic. Boyer, whose only previous match in Indian Wells was a first-round qualifying encounter as a 16-year-old seven years ago, will next take on his countryman and 10th seed Tommy Paul.

Thiago Seyboth Wild and Christopher O‚ÄôConnell each notched three-set triumphs to kick-start their BNP Paribas Open campaigns. Seyboth Wild saved two match points in the deciding set before prevailing 4-6, 7-5, 7-6(6) against Alexandre Muller, while O‚ÄôConnell won a topsy-turvy duel with Roberto Carballes Baena 6-3, 0-6, 6-1. In the second round, Seyboth Wild will take on last week‚Äôs Dubai champion Stefanos Tsitsipas, while O‚ÄôConnell plays Matteo Berrettini.
